The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Sues for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Adem. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinsi) el Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: SHERI LAW IN EGYPT.
div.p: Pending the result of the labours of the Committee whose task is, subject to the sanction of the Council of Ministers, to Codify I into one system the four sections of the Sheri, I or religious law, a brief statement of what I these sections are will be of interest. The four I sects are the Hanafi, Shafi, Maliki, and Ham-1 beli. They profess to be, Sunnites, or orthodox I adherents to the traditions of the Koran, as I opposed to those whom they consider Shiya, I or heretics, to wit'ïho Persians. These sects I of Orthodoxy owe their rise to a difference of I opinion respecting points oÇréligion and law, I as held by the doctors after whom they are I named. The Turks believe in the Hanafi rite, I which is recognised as official by the Imperia! I Government. In Cairo, this sect is small in I comparison with the Shafi, who prevail also in I the Delta, Sharkieh, and Arabia. In tho Behe-11 ra the Maliki predominate, and the sect extends 11 to the Upper Nile, including the Nubians and I < Western Arabs.There is, too, a sprinkling of the I Maliki in the Delta itself. The fourth sect is, I like the Wahabis of Egypt, insignificant. All I sects agree as to the fourfold source of their I religion and law, which is . the Koran, the I traditions of Mohamed, tho concordance of his I - early disciples, and analogy. Thus, in view of I ‘ the harmony which unites tho four sects, the I labour of embodying their tenets into a code I will be both light and afford, in the eventof a I happy issue, general, satisfaction amongst the 1 adhorents to the four sects in Egypt. We must I anticipate somo faint echo of Turkish thunder I J at this disrespect Vf a rite which is official in I . the 1 Ottoman dominions, but we regard it as I j me proof the more to Tgrkey of the new order 11 >f things in Nile Land. j

div.head: NEW HEBRIDES CONVENTION. COLONIAL PREMIERS' PROTEST
div.p: The Premiers of the Commonwealth and I New Zealand have protested to Lord Elgin against the signing of the New Hebrides Con- ! vention, which they consider ùnduly favours I the Frenoh olaims at the expense of British I and Australian interests. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NEWFOUNDLAND FISHERIES. A SATISFACTORY COMPROMISE
div.p: In consideration ot the Americans agreeing not to nse purse and seines, the Newfound- I landers agree to refrain from fishing daring I the night time. Night fishing has been a fertile source of trouble owing to the men cutting one I another’s nets. The oompromise reduces tbe I possibility of friction to a minimum. (Reuter)

div.p: M. Cambon has been appointed Secretary to the Embassy at Rome. (Havas)

div.head: CHINES ARMY MANEUVRES
div.p: Thirty foreign attachés are attending the I Autumn macoenvres, oarried ont by 80,000 I troops, in the vioinity of Changtefn, nnder the loommand of Ynanshikai and Tiehliang. The troops are armed with modern weapons and drilled by foreign officers. (Reuter)

div.head: SALVAGE OF THE LUTIN.
div.p: The Lutin has been partly raised and towed into shallower water. (Reuter)

div.head: INQUEST ON MR. MACFADYEN
div.p: An inquest has been held on the remains of Mr. Maofadyen. A verdiot of “nnsonnd mind" was returned. The railway .officials testified to finding the mangled body in the Tube tonnel. Death had possibly resulted from electocution. (Reuter)
New Cab Tariff. The new cab tariff for Keneh town is to be issued in tbe coarse of this week.
Sale of Chizeh It is reported tbat Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel bas sold bis palace at Ghizsh for L.E. 400,000.
The Brindisi Mall. The mail from Eorope, viâ. Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 9 p.m. to-day.

Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The Ministry of the Interior has recognised the establishment of a branch of tbe Cairo Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals at Beni Souef.

Khédivial Medloal Sooiety. A meeting of the Khédivial Medioal Sooiety will be held on Saturday, November 3. Subjeota for discussion and communications will be accepted by the secretary up to the 28th inst.-

Druse and Bedouin. A serious affray between Druses and Bedouins is reported to have occurred thirty miles from Damascus. There were heavy losses on both sides. Tbe disorder was, however, hemmed in by the Turkish trroops.

H M S. Terrible. Our Suez Correspondent reports that H.M.S. Terrible, wbiob lost her Btarboard propeller and 8 feet of her tail shaft near Singapore, arrived at Suez yesterday afternoon with one propeller. She will go into drydock at Malta.

Egyptian Cotton for Japan. Japan is ceasing to use Surat cotton, and is c.nsoming a quantity of Egyptian. She is rapidly extending her cotton industry. Daring the last two years she has nearly doubled her lumber of looms, whilst twenty years ago the trade was almost nil. Employment's given to 10,000 persons.

New Army Hospital. The Sirdar, Sir P. R. Wingate Pasba, and Major-General Bullock, G.O.C., accompanied by their respective staffs, have paid a visit to the new hospital of the Egyptian Army re- ssntly built at Koubbch. The Sirdar congratulated Mr. Watson, the oontraotor, on the ixcellent arrangements oi the building, which is thoroughly up-to-date.

Jardin Franoais. The entertainment provided in the theatre n the French Garden continues to attract urge audiences nightly. After having renewed ;he engagement of Mr. "Gyp," the famous smale> impersonator, the management have lecured the services of “Libre et Change,” well- mown comedians from the El Dorado at Paris, vho will make their débût this evening.

Suez Canal. On the,20th and 21st October 25 vessels, if which. 10 were northward and 15 southward jound, transited the canal, and paid for rransit and passenger toll Fr. 645,511.48. Of ihese 12 were British, 5 German, 3 /French, 1 Italian, 1 Dutch, 1 Norwegian, 1 Egyptian, and L Spanish. The total receipts since Ootober 1 are Fr, 5,757,651.29 and daring that time 213 ressels transited the Canal, 94 being northward, aud 119 southward bound.

div.head: BOTTLING THE JORDAN. PROGRESS OF AMERICAN SCHEME
div.p: Considerable interest is being taken in Palestine in the sobeme of an American company to export the waters of the Jordan River to the United States to serve for baptismal and other religions purposes.

Colonel Nadaud, the president of the International River Jordan Water Company, has been at tbe Jordan for the last fortnight with a staff of 20 men, who are busily engaged in boiling, filtering, and disinteoting 60,000 kilos, (equalling thirty tons) of river water. The water is being placed in barrels of 600 kilos, oapaoity, and each barrel has to be thoroughly cleaned and steamed inside with boiling water and sods, then washed again with a disinfectant in order to kill what germs may lurk in the wool.

The greatest precautions are being taken to ensure the absolute purity of the water, whiob, I am assured by Colonel Nadaud, will reaoh the consumer in as pure a condition, if not as fresh, as spring water. He tells me that, if need be, it may be drunk by a baby with perfect safety.

Every barrel^f the water will be sealed by the seal of the Amerioan Consul at Jerusalem, under his supervision at tbe Jordan, also under the sopervisjon of a Turkish soldier, and of the Patriarch of Jerusalem, who will be represented by a monk sent here from St. John’s Convent, near the Jordan. The seal of each barrel will only be broken as it is used in Newjifork City, U.S. A., in a Government warehouse, by an authorized committee, and bottled only under their supervision.

The company's camp and working scene at the Jordanie b great and most unusual sight. Natives in olArge of large camel oaravans and tourists to the Jordan crowd around the camp at all hours to. ascertain what it all means.

div.head: WHITE SLAVE TRADE. CONGRESS IN PARIS
div.p: M. Fallières has received the members of the congress for the repression of the white slave traffio. The Egyptian delegate was presented by M. Berenger. ( Hams)

div.head: A SUEZ PETITION.
div.p: A petition has been presented by the steamship agents and merchants of Suez, to Mr. A. Williams, Director of Customs, praying bim to do what he can to indnoe the Government to dredge the creek leading to Suez. Everybody most sincerely hopes that Mr. Williams, who takes such an interest in the welfare of Suez, will succeed in persuading the authorities to dredge the creek, which at low tide is impassable to steam launobes and lighters. Naturally this is a great drawback to the oommerce of the town as well as a serions delay to shipping. The general opinion is that the creek, once dredged, would last for many years, and tbe work is not expeoted to Bntail any heavy expenditure.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: the Khedive is spending the day on bis estates at Mariout, whither he proceeded yesterday. On Friday evening he will give an ",ftar” at Ras-el-Tin Palaoe to the notable native merchants of Alexandria.
His Highness will receive Lord Cromer in private audience at Ras-el-Tin Palace on Friday next.

div.head: MIXED TRIBUNALS
div.p: According to the estimates of the Ministry of Justice for 1907, two new judgeships are to be created in the Mixed Courts of Cairo Bnd Alexandria. The vacancies will probably be filled by Sfeediah and Norwegian judges.
The Ministry of Justice has selected a Portuguese judge for the Mixed Court of Mansourab, and the appointment is expected to be confirmed by the Portuguese Government.
The Swedish judge at the Mansourah Mixed Court will be transferred shortly to the Court" of Alexandria.
M. Antoniades, Counsellor in the Mixed Court of Appeal, Cairo, resigned his offish yesterday.
M. de Beruardie, French Counsellor of the Cairo Mixed Court of Appeal, intends to resign shortly, and he will probably be replaced by M. Prunières, of the Cairo Mixed Court of 1st Instance.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENT
div.p: The S.S. Creole Prit ce left Malta yesterday with passengers and general cargo, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Saturday.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH PROFESSOR BIER'S STATEMENT.
div.p: Professor Bier has left. He has declared that the Sultan is cured of the simple catarrh of the bladder from which he suffered. (H)

div.head: "ARE WE FANATICAL?" NATIVE PRESS OPINION
div.p: Dealing with the subject of the alleged wave of fanaticism in Egypt, “A1 Manar” says : - The sympathy shown by Egypt towards Turkey in the Akaba and other affairs should not be considered as a purely religious fanatioism which may do harm to Christians. England and the other European nations admit that Turkey is Egypt’s suzerain power ; but neither does Egypt wish to give up her independence for Turkey’s sake, nor does Turkey ever think of doing away with that independence. Then Akaba is a very important point with regard to the Hedjsz Railway and to the Holy Places of Islam, and no one accepts to have his holy places governed by a man who professes another religion. Most of those who accuse us of fanaticism are the mouth-piece of diplomacy. Diplomacy is an unintelligible language : it is like the oraoles wbioh are understood only after the event has taken place. We are not diplomats, but we will tell the diplomats the following truth. We do not deny that we desire to be allowed to govern onrselveB ; ' but this is only human. You cannot oall that I fanaticism. We do not take advantage of the troubles of foreign governments to attaok them : tbe Mohamedaus in Russia are not doing what the other inhabitants of tbe country are doing now. If you want us to live peacefully together and our interests to. be reconciled it will be easy of attainment. We want justice, equity, etc. It was by these qualities that Islam,oonquered a large part of the world in less than a century. We see that you do not waul to be our equals even in our own countries wbioh we rule ourselves ; and you say that our religion teaokes fanaticism.

The gist of the whole thing is that Islam is the most just of all religions ; tbat it was the Europeans who awoke the feeling of fanatioism in us ; that the Mohamedans educated in European schools are nearer to fanatioism than those sduoated at the Azhar ; that this fanaticismis ! cot to be feared dnless all the Christians I should unite together against Islam with the { intention of wiping it out ; that- the Sultan ! oannot order a general war exoept under these j jiroumstances ; that the meaning of the word ,j "fanatioism” asmsed by Sir E. Grey was that J given above; that this feeling awoke in the days of the Akaba affair, and that Lord Cromer I feared troubles, so he took the necessary | measures to avoid them ; that the Denishwai sffair bad nothing to do with fanatioism—it j was due rather to the savageness of the villagers ; that England has inflioted a severe punishment in order to set an example to ] jthers ; that England has lost the sympathy of I the people, which sympathy she might regain if everything goes on well now ; that the Egyptians are the least striot among the Mohamedans.

The Mohamedans may be divided into three categories: The Ulema, like the Azhar people, who study religion; those who study European ionone’s, and the common people. The first snow the precepts of tbe Koran about dis- J (enters living among us that they should be well treated and protected, etc. The only thing igainst this class of Mohamedans is that they ■ ire not sociable with the dissenters. The j second category are as ignorant (as regards I religion) as the common herd, but they are/] inclined to fanaticism for a political purpose ; fanaticism was fanned in them when they became acquainted with Europe’s ambition and its opinion of Islam. The third category are the lommon people. They are simple and good- learned. True, they believe that they ought to them the Sultan, etc., but if any aggression is feared, they can be calmed by the ulema’s lemons in the mosques. May Europe know ;hat we are not fanatic, the man nearest to religion among us is the farthest away from fanaticism ; and the man nearest to fanaticism a he who is well acquainted with European civilisation.

div.head: TURKISH PAPER ON AKABA.
div.p: Anent the Akaba affair, the Turkish news- japer “Sanjak” states that this has been olosed :o the satisfaction of Great Britain. To. Ghati Vfukhtar Pasha attaches all the blame for laving raised a question wbioh has strengthen- sd British influence in Egypt and afforded the Jconpation a means of securing a permanent hold therein.

Commenting on the above statement, tbe “Mokattam” points to the striking contrast tetween Turkey, the suzerain ot Egypt, which does not deny ‘the troth of the Egyptian Question, and the Egyptians, who state that Great Britain has no official or legal status in the Nile Valley.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY
div.p: In the last /‘‘Revue de Paris" the editor concludes his article on Arabia. The liberation of Egypt, he writes, seems to be one of the aims of Turkish policy. The 8ultan has never been reconciled to the English occupation, and though he has maintained territorial limits and political conditions, he is in the humour for wishing to change these conditions. If the Kaiser and the Saltan do not want war, the Akabsh railway might in the hands of tbe English become the instrument of a more misohievons policy than Ottoman power. The Saltan under German protection, and the Ottoman peoples under the influence of England—that is the result of the Turkith Empire after fifteen years of Abdul Hamid’s ] régime. ,

div.head: ENGLISH OPERA IN CAIRO "THE RUNAWAY GIRL"
div.p: The Bandmann Opera Company gave their seoond performance of the season at the Khédivial Opera House, Cairo, last night with "A Runaway Girl," whioh wasagreat improvement on "Lady Madoap.” The company had manifestly leoovered from whatever fatigue their voyage had oaused them. Miss Corlass had also recovered her voioe, enjl the orchestra showed far more ease and unanimity. Miss Corlass, as the Runaway Girl, and Mr. Hany Cole, as Slipper, were the two brillant stars above all the rest. Mr. Cole kept bis audienoe in fits of laughter, especially as “the Man from Cook’s,” and in his scene with the two brigands, the latter fulfilled all the traditions of Surrey side melodrama and had quite the proper command of their oloaks and daggers. Miss Leslie’s Italian song was excellent, though a little hard here and there. Carmenita, Alioe, aud Lord and Lady Coodle were all good. Mr. Attwell, as Stanley, was also excellent. The pieoe contained many oharming old favourites. The singing, of "Guriy Burly” was a great suooess for Mr. Cole, as was also "The Kind of Girl I hear about,” and, of course, “3oldiete in the Park.” The rendering of/ill these songs met with due appreciation. The "Goblin and Picoaninny” song is rather dragged in by the heels, but that always happens with the “ruusioal comedies” of the present day. The musio, too, is quite pretty. The only difficulty to be overcome is the stage itself. The chorus is small for so large a horse, and the principals have not yet mastered tbe range of the theatre. But to oooolude: if the other performances are on a par with 'Tbe Runaway Girl” we may well be pleased, and with three such excellent performers as Miss Georgia Corlass, Mr. Attwell, and Mr. Cole, no pieoe oould possibly fall fiat.

div.head: NEW INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL
div.p: The president of the Orwa Woska Society even informed that the Ministry of Finance has decided to make a grant of L.E. 3,000 to the society for the Mohamed Ali School of Industries at Alexandria. The school, which is a magnificent building, was designed for by Hassabu Bey Mohamed, an active member of the committee, who has. Now been charged with the provision of machiner^ and is in communication with British firms for its supply.

The school was inspected the other day by Fakhry Pasha and Mr. Danlop, who expressed themselves as greatly pleased with the building, and asked for a copy of the plans for the Ministry of Public Instruction.

div.head: GREEK LADY KILLED IN LONDON
div.p: Mrs. Rodocanachi, a Greek lady, residing at 2, Clarendon-place, Hyde Park-square, London, was killed this day week by falling from her bed-room window to the area below, a distance of about 35lt. Shé had been for some time in bad health, and was attended by a nurse.

About nine o’clock the latter left her for a few minutes, and almost immediately afterwards Mrs. Rodooanaohi was found lying in her night attire in front of the house, with severe injuries to the head. She died very.soon afterwards.

She was a widow, of about about 60 years of age, and had several daughters residing with her. She belonged to a wealthy Greek family, who have been established many years in England and are well known in Egypt.

div.head: HELOUAN AS A HEALTH RESORT
div.p: Still one more has been added to the many volumes written on Helouan as a health and pleasure resort, by Dr. H. Overton Hobson, with the title of "Helouan : Ad Egyptian Health Resort ana How to Reaoh It." (Longmans, Green & Co., LondoD.2s.6d.). The book is well-printed, illustrated with thirty-five excel lent photographs, and its oontents are both instructive and interesting. A long chapter is deservedly devoted to the baths, of which Dr. Hobson is medioal director, and mineral waters of Helouan, which are of course the most prominent attractions of this desert city, and the general information given at the end of the book is most comprehensive. The now varied amusements of Helouan are well dealt with, and the book also contains some good descriptions of places of interest in and around the city.

div.head: ST. CYRIL OF ALEXANDRIA
div.p: lu tbe ‘Ttsvue d’Histoire Eooléiiastique” Père Josepf'Mahé prints an artiole upon "Les Anathématismee de Saint Cyrille d’Alexandrie et les Evêques Orientaux du patriarchat d’Antioche.” This essay is of much interest to stadents of the history of Egyptian Christianity. As is well knowu, this treatise of Cyril's was in opposition to the dootrines ot Nestorius and was a polemical production of the Alexandrian theologian preliminary to tbe celebrated Churoh Counoil at Ephesus. The Ana- themata were forwarded to Antioch, to the prelates there aud created such stirring literary effasious in reply, tbat Cyril hurriedly composel a series of Apologies in answer to the remonstranoei addressed to him. This seoond treatise Father Mahé considers was oomposed and circulated previous to the Ephesus Coynoil Meeting. Ha gives a new edition with ample commentary of Cyril's work.

div.head: EGYPTIAN EDUCATION. THE UNIVERSITY SCHEME.
div.p: (Conclusion.)

What the education reformers ask for is the study of “Arabic and European literature, sciences, philosophy, and history.” Coaid not the Education Department provide this 1 The mistake the Government have made is to reduce the years in the Secondary school from three to two : students will not be prepared to enter the advanced secondary schools under three years. Let the Government first restore that year. Then, what is to be studied in the advanced S3oondary school 1 Apparently the syllabus continues the same studies which were formerly included in the third year of the old Secondary school, and adds a certain number of subjects which are taught at present in the different Higher schools as introductory to the more professional subject there taught. The work of the Higher schools is lessened, or the subjects now taught in four years are spread over five. Apart from that there is little change; and yet here is the material ready at hand to fill in some at least of the “gaps.”

To evert to the former three years in the Secondary schools: give a Secondary certificate to all students who pass an examination at the end of that period; allow successful students either to enter the Government service, or proceed to the advanced Secondary school. The work in this new school should over a period of not less than three years; in this period the Begets of study should be arranged in classes; certain subjects should be compulsory to all students, others should be voluntary, certain subjects being alternative, others according to the future intentions of the student. If the student intends to enter a particular higher school he should be obliged to take certain of the alternative subjects especially suited as preparatory to his future professional étudié», but, if the student desires simply to enter the Government service, or to retire into private life, his choice should be lass restricted. At the end of the three years all successful students should receive a diploma in arts which would qualify them either to enter a higher professional school, or to apply for a more important post in the Government service than is open to a student who has only a Secondary certificate.

What of the new syllabus? What subjects are to be compulsory for all, and what alternative 1 “Arabic and European literature, sciences, philosophy, and history." There should at any rate be ample room for these. Arabic literature must be compulsory, the very backbone of the whole course of study. If English be a study, whether compulsory or alternative, attention should be concentrated on English literature rather than en grammar. An about of the Constitution of Egypt should certainly be given to all students, whether they intend to become doctors or merely dilettanti. It passes understanding why this subject is at present only taught to lawyers; such all educated persons in Egypt should know something about the constitution of the country; hew otherwise are Egyptians to understand the constitutional changes foreshadowed in Lord Cromer’s last Report how otherwise are Egyptians to be prepared to take a larger share in the government of the State, as we are given to understand by the Native Press is their present desire? History is worth a place among the compulsory subjects; while among the voluntary subjects mathematics might alternate with a special period of history, such as that of Rome: and the natural sciences with French or Italian, or political economy, or political science. There are plenty of subjects to choose from, each with its own peculiar value, and what should make the task of the Government easier is the fact that living in the archives of the Ministry of Education is a syllabus prepared for just such a school as this; a syllabus which must have been living there now for some years; a syllabus prepared by an authority on education who realised that this “gap” existed and did his best to induce the Government to fill it.

The development of a higher school such as this would be the adoption of a system, well-understood in France and in Scotland, two countries in which education has always taken a prominent place in the minds of the people, in these countries no student may proceed theprofessional study such as law, until he has obtained a diploma of arts. It may be said that students would hesitate to undertake so long a? course of study; that to add yet three more years to the student career of a lawyer would prevent many young Egyptians entering the profession. But Would this not be a blessing rather than otherwise 1 If the figures given by the “Gazette” are correct, no less than 100 new students entered thé English section of the Law School and fifty the French section. Will there be work for a continuous output of one hundred and fifty qualified lawyers a year 1 If students who have received the legal diploma of the School of Law, cannot find work, will the popularity of that school continue 1 Is there not a serious danger in increasing the supply so much beyond the probable demand 1 I speak more particularly of the School of Law since the figures have already been made public; the position of the other Professional Schools may be the same. Bat the School of Law, at present, occupies a special position; it is the highest school to which students naturally elect to go if they do not desire to enter any particular profession, but wish to continue their studies a stage beyond the present secondary schools. It is natural that this should be so, and the authorities recognize the fact by including a number

of what ate not striotly legal subjeots in the oourse of studies of the School of Law ; subjects a neb as political eoonomy, political science, and the constitutional history of Egypt ; subjeots which-1 have suggested should form a part of the rurrioulsm of the advanoed secondary school, or tbe sohool of art; a* we may oall it.

There does not seem any prima facie argument against the Government itself undertaking to fill this most serious "gap” in tbe education of the young Egyptian. Private enterprise is undoubtedly the best, and produces the best moral good ; but under pneseut conditions, private enterprise bas an almost impossible task to fulfil iu trying to oempete with government enterprise. Under the circumstances, the Government might give farther proof of its broad-mindedness by oarrying its education system just one step further, and thereby answering the appeal of a very influential oirole of its Egyptian subjeots, both Moslems and Christian. "Our people have oame to the conclusion that its system of éducation is incomplete; that its limits are too narrow ; that it ends too soon !”
lord Cromer is coming to Alexandria from Cairo on Friday next to pay a visit to the Khedive.
Mazloum Pasha, Minister of Finanoe, hae returned to Egypt from his hol'day.
Miralai Owen Bey and Naoum Bey Shake» are due in Cairo at 11.30 this evening from Suez.

Judge Archer, of the Mixed Coart of let Instance, is leaving Alexandria fir England at the end of the month in order to take aphis new post as Counsellor to tbe Siamese Legation in London, in suooeesion to Mr. F. Verney, the son of Sir Harry Verney, who has entered Parliament.
Lady Anne Blunt is leaving England on tbe 6th proxo. for Egypt.

Mr. C. C. James, the well-known Anglo- Indian sanitary engineer, is now in Cairo, and is energetically occupied with the drainage question of that city. Mr. James is the author of several volumes on Oriental drainage works.
Mr. and Mrs. Montagu Sommets are staying at Shepheard’s Hotel.
George Nungovich Bey and Mr. Constantine Meimaraohi are arriving at Alexandria on Saturday next by tbe Htuburg-Amerioan S.8.
Oceana.

For the first time sinoe the King ascended the throne he has stayed for two or three days at Moulton Paddocks with Sir Ernest Cassel. Sir Ernest Cassel has spout a very large sou ot money on Moulton Paddooka sinoe be purchased it from the late Lord Girard, who aba in his time did a good deal for the place. The grounds are very delightful, with great shady trees close up to the house, but naturally it is moredelighlfal in summer than in autumn.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
La Délégation Municipals s’est réunie le SI octobre 1906 à 9 h. du soir sous la préûdenee de 3.E. le Dr Sohiess Paoha.

Communication est donnée d’une lettre de 17 octobre 1906 du Ministère de l’Infétient remettant les détails et renseignements que la Municipalité l’avait prié de vouloir bien lei fournir en vue du projet de oonstruotioa de • ponts sur le canal Mahmoudieh.

Ces trois ponts coderont LE. 18,500 environ, sur ^quelles le Gouvernement a promis une contribution de LE. 6000, le restant devant être supporté par la Municipalité et las Associations et Scolétéi intéressées.
Cette lettre sera soumise à la Commission Municipale dans sa prochaine séance.
La Délégation renvoie à l’examen du Comité spécial chargé de la révision des allocations une demande du Khédivial Yaoht Club tendant è majorer l’allocation qni loi est allouée.
Une eéanoe de oe Comité, en vue de l’étude des allocations inscrites au budget et des demandes nouvelles, est fixée pour mercredi 31 ootobre 1916 à 9 h. du soir.

La Délégation, sur lk demande de propriétaires riverains, accepte de contribuer pour moitié dans la construction d’une oanalisation devant desservir les immeubles de là rae Ragbeb Paoha, et partant de oette rue pour déverser dans l’égont de la rue dp let Khédive.
M. Kaster ayant demandé le pavage d'une ruelle, conduisant à son dépôt, près de là me dénommée Borham Paoha, sauf é prendre à sa charge la moitié delà dépense, L Délégation aooepte.

Vu la note dn service de la voirie demandant des instructions pour la continuation du pavage des rues suivant le programme établi an cours de l’exercioe, la Délégation décide la réfeotion d’ores et déjà du pavage en dalles de la rue Caied Gohar ainsi què le complément de pavage des parties de rues non encore dallées depuis la rua Baidawi jusqu’au Département des tabaosà la Douane.
Elle demandera également à la Commission un orédit supplémentaire de 2 à 8,000 L.E. pour permettre la continuation du pavage dee rues portées au programme.

p.note:
La Délégation autorisa une dépense de L.E. 124 environ pour rétablissement de canalisations supplémentaires devant servir au déversement des eaux provenant des tanneries dn Max, saof à récupérer des propriétaires la moitié de la dépense an fpr et à mesure de lenrs demandes d’embranchement.
La Délégation s'ocoupe de la question de l’insnffiianoe des carrières actuelle?.
Sur rapport des services, one superficie de
m.o. des oarrières munioipales du Mex, réprésentant un oubage de 500.000 m. cubes pourrait être mis à la disposition des carriers, quantité qui serait denature b satisfaire pour qne'que temps aux besoittsyles entrepreneurs.
Cependant, il y aurait lieu d'envisager l’éventualité prochaine de l’épuisement des oarrièreB disponibles pour'les besoins des particuliers au Mex.et d’entamer les pourparlers déjà engagés aveo l’administration des Chemins de ter pour l’établissement d’nne ligne reliant la ville aux oarrières de Dekeila, en vue de l'exploitation de oelles-oi.
Conformément an désir du Ministère, l’admi nistration est invitée à se mettre d'accord avec le service des bâtiments de l'Etat en vue du règlement de oette question.
Là Délégation prend connai-ssnoe des avis émis par le Comité des travaux publies an sujet de diverses questions soumises à son examen, et qui ont trait an sons-lotissement des parcelles des quais, dans la zsnequi s'étend de la Poste au Victoria College, an terrain à réserver comme dépêt des pastèques près de la cale sèche, et enfin au mur de soutènement de l’hôpital indigène.
La Délégation charge l'Administration de procéder aux évaluations approximatives des expropriations nécessaires pour la continuation de l’élargissement de la rne Bab-el-Karasts, jusqu’à la rue Anastasi. .
Elle prend oonn&issanoe d’une dépêche de la Municipalité de Berlin proposant comme candidat an poste d’ingénieur en chef, Mr. Nier, ingénieur Municipal de la Ville de Dresde. Cette lettre sera soumise à la Commission.
Sur la demande de Mr. PiotBey, la Déléga- . tion propose à la Commission une dépense de L E. 300 pour l’installation à l’abattoir d’une presse hydraulique destinés à réduire les contenus des estomacs et des intestins en on volume insignifiant, permettant de les brûler dans les chaudières et d’éviter aiosi toute oon- tagion possible. alt; La séanoe est levée à 11 h. du soir

div.p: (Auiourd hui à midi et demie.)

Un revirement complet s’est produit ce matin sur notre marché. La fermeté a repris le dessus avec tendance prononcée à la hausse snr toute la ligne. On attribue ce changement inattendu à oe que des positions se sont repor- - téss en grand nombre pour fin novembre, ce qui écarte le danger d’une liquidation trop laborieuse pour fin ootobre. Ajoutons que les re ports payés sont excessivement ohers.

La reprise est générale, bien que les affaires demeurent limitées aux National B»nk, Daïrs, Cassa di Sconto, Nungovich Hotels, Delta Land, Nile Land et Estates. Sur nombre d’autres titres il y a demande assez aotive sans vendeurs. C'est œ qni explique la hausse.

De 27 1/16 la National Bank' s’avance à 27 1/4, la Daïrade 16 11/16 àl^ 7/8, la Béhéra de 39 1/4 à 39 1/2, la Cassa di Sconto de 237 1/2 et 932 1/2 à 238 1/4 et 933 1/4, les Nungovich Hotels de 18 à 18 5/16. U Nile Land de 16 à 16 1/4, la Khédivial Mail de 4 5/8 à 4 3/4, le Comptoir de 6 29/32 et 6 5/8 à 6 15/16 et 6 21/32 l'aotion et de 48 à 49 la part de fonda tear, le Crédit Franoo-Egyptien de 5‘5/l6 à 5 7/16.
Les Markets se relèvent de 25/6 à 26/3 acheteurs.
L’Ànglo-American Nile, depuis longtemps stationnaire à 5 1/2, mob te à 5 3/4 acheteurs.
De 3 25/32 la Delta Land remonte à 3 27/32
En grande faveur les aotions Estates sont demandées à 2 1/8, soit 3/32 de hausse ; les parta de fondateur cotent 15 1/4-1/2.
L’Union Fonoière est l’objet d’une demande Boivie à 6 1/4, sans vendeurs.
Par contre, l’ObligationCrédit Foncier Egyp tien reonle de 336 à 335, l’Ordinary Khédivial Mail de 35/9 à 35/3, la Building Lands de 4t 7/8,jk 4 3/4 et la Banque d’Orient de 134 1/2 àl

Commé on le voit, la reprise est accentuée et l’animation de la séance peut se comparer à I celle des pins beaux jours. Si les positions continuent à se reporter, la liquidation de fi i courant passera sans encombre, ainsi que les précédentes.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny. NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: 1 Le Caire, 23 Octobre.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres se maintient à 6 %. Hier, au Stock Exohange, le Consolidé anglais est reetéunvarié à 85 7/8 et l’Unifiée à 104. La National'Bank a perdo 1/8 à 27. La Dsïra a gagné 1/8 à 17. L’Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 9 7/8, de même que la Delta Light à 12.

A Paris, l’aotion Crédit Fonoier Egyptien a rétrogradé de 2 franos à 776. La Banque d’Aihènes est restes stationnaire à 144. L’Em prunt russe 1906 a passé de 84.30 à 84 50 ; à Londres, il a haussé de 79 3/4 à 80 1/2.

Ici, la tenue d’ensemble du marohé a été à peu près semblable à celle d’hier. Ou est resté dans le calme et dans l’expectative, en se maintenant pins on moins ferme sûr tonte la cote. Les vues sont, généralement, optimistes ; mais encore attend-on nne détente réelle de la tension monétaire pour s’orienter vers la re prise. A noter, comme trait car&c'éristitjue de la matinée, un mouvement sur la Cassa di Sconto, déterminé par la rumeur que les petites difficultés concernant le doublement du capital de cette Banque auraient é’é aplanies et qu’en outre le titré serait prochainement admis à la c'ote de Paris.

Dans le compartiment des Banque?, la National a été traitée à 27 pour clôturer à 26 15/16. L’Agricole a molli à 9 3/4 et la Banque d'Athènes à 144-145. La Cassa di Sconto a atteint, au débat de la Béance, 242 poor revenir aussitôt après à 233 et olôturer à 237. Le Comptoir Financier a progressé à 6 15/16-7 .’notion anc'rajne et 6 13/16 la nouvelle. La Banque d'Abfssin:e est revenue à 5 5/8.

Le Crédit Fonoier a été mieux tenu à 779- 780. La Daï-a a faibli à 16 11/16-3/4. La Béhéra est remontée à 39,3/4-40. La part de fondateur Immobilière a rétrogradé à 740. L’Enterprise and Development a fléchi à 12 5/8. ; la part de fondateur a, par contre, gagné 1 livre à 22 1/2. En bonne tendance, la-part de fondateur Wardan a passé de 8 1/16 à^)3/l-9.

L’aotion Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été négociée à 4 7/16-1/2 ; la part de fondateur a atteint 99-100 pcnr ’finir à 98. Les Improvements ont fait 5 15/16-6^ L’aotion Allotment a avancé à 3 25/32 pour o'ôtnrer à

list.item: 3/4; la part de fondateur a hiussé à 155 pour revenir à 148 et terminer à 151.

div.p: La Delta Light a faibli à 11 15/16. L’Hélio- polisaé'.é traité à 316-317. Les Automobiles se sont encore alourdies à 6 et leur part de fondateur à 11 3/4. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire se sont raffermies à 268-269. La Frigorifique a avancé à 4 13/16. t
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovioh se sont consolidés à 18 et les Egyp tian à 7. Les Upper Egypt ont été recherchés à 5 3/8-7/18. -

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Laud ont été ramenés à 3 3/4-1316. Les New Egyp tiansont remontés à 33 sh. 6, Les Estates se sont raffermis à 2 1/16; lent part de fondateur a progressé à 15 1/8. Les Constructions ont été négociées à 1 1/2-9/16 et les Khédivial Mail à 35 sh. 6.
Nous détaobons d’une lettre de Paris, en date dn 16 Octobre, le passage suivant :

“La question de l’argent, ou plutôt dn taux de l’argent, a été, la semaine dernière, par suite de la l'quidation de qnir.ziine, nn grand sujet à préoccupations pour les acheteurs désireux de sa faire reporter et qui pouvaient craindre de voir les profits de leurs opérations entamés par le prix élevé des reports Ces craintes ne fe sont pas toutefois réalisées, et la liquidation s’est effectuée plus aisément qu’on le pensait C’est que précisément les appréhensions qu'elle snsoitrit ont provoqué on grand nombre d’allègements, de telle sotte que, pour une grosse part, la liquidation s’est faite, pour aine: dire, par anticipation. Il c’en est pas moinsVxact de reconnaître que le taux de 4 et

list.item: 1/2 environ, qui a été pratiqué hier pour les reports, est un peu plus élevé que le normal ; mais il n’est pas excessif et peut même passer pour modéré en regard de là ten?ion monétaire aotuelle.

div.p: La bonne tenue des notions du Crédit Fonoier Egyptien est attribuée à une rameur suivant laquelle le dividende de l’exercice en cours pourrait bien être sensiblement sapé rieur à telni de l’année précédente.”

Nous avons annoncé, la semaine dernière, q*e les actionnaires de la Société Anonyme Agricole et Industrielle d’Egypte sont convoqués en assemblée générale extraordinaire pour le 27 Novembre prochain au siège social, à Anvers, à l'effet de délibérer sur une augmentation du capital, avec émission au pair pour les anciens actionnaires, et sur la création d’obligations nouvelles.
Lé capital notions actuel de cotte Société est de 10,000,000 de francs, représentéJpar

list.item: aotions de Fre. 500. Le capital obligations s’élève à environ Fr. 23 000,00’'. Il y a
parts de fondateur, sans désignation de \aleur, dont le prix actuel e’t de f-,215 francs. L’aotion est cotée 975 francs.

div.p: Les propriétés de la Société représentent nne superfioie de 41,668 fsddans, dont le coût total est de L.E. 1,425,667. La balance du compte Profits et Pertes de l'exercice terminé le 31 Janvier 1906 s’élevait à L.E 104.031.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM. MR. BLUNT'S VIEWS
div.p: Under this title Mr. Wilfrid Sciwen Blnnt indiots Lord Cromer’s Egyptian policy in the "/□dependent Review.” Lord Cromer’s “veiled Protectorate,” adopted as a compromise between Gladstone’s policy of evacuation and Hartington’s polioy of annexation, was never, hy its author, so the writer maintains, intended to promote the “prudent development of Egypt’s institutions.” He asserts- that after introducing many reforms widely advertised by Lord Milner and other agents in the Press, Lord Cromer this year assumed fall authority, and there oame a ooneeqnent resurreotion of Egyptian nationalism. Egypt is becoming oon- vinoed of England’s ill faith. All reforms are now understood as fattening the ox for the slaughter, or preparing Egypt for annexation. The dread of this on the part of Egyptians is legitimate and natural, Mr. Blunt thinks, and not to be set down to the fanatical excesses of Pan-Islamism.
Not Pan-lslamlsm.
Of Pan IalamiBm he claims to know more than any Englishman. He says :—

“I know its strength and its weakness. I know its fanatioal side, and I know its side of reform and progress. I know what its value is in Arabia, in India, at Constantinople, and in the Bahara no less than in Egypt. I have been for the last twenty five years on intimate terms with several of its chief exponents.

I sympathise with it, and in its Liberal sense I wish it well. My words, therefore, may have weight when I affirm that the current talk about it, as applied to the Egyptian f movement, of which at the present momentMnstapha Kamel is the most able advocate, is mere diplomatic mystification. There is next to no connection in reality between the fellahin of the Delta and the great fanatical brotherhood of the Sahara, the Senoussia, with which the French ate in difficulties farther west. Nor are the fellahin fanatically affeoted by any propaganda from Constantinople. In Egypt there is no hatred for religion’s sake either towards Christians or Jews as snoh, or even race enmity, exceptât Alexandria, always a turbulent half European oity criminally inclined.” Homo Rule for Egypt.

Mr. Blnnt affirm» that there is in^Egypt no love for the Saltan, bnt "the man in the j aws of the lion oalls out to the tiger for help, and in the grip of an English officialdom Egypt may well oast her eyes at times in the direc tion of Constantinople.” Bnt -.—"What Mnsta- pha Kamel and the Nationalists want is Home Rule for Egypt under the Ottoman Crown. Absolute independence they would perhaps prefer, but they look at this for the present as too dangerous a freedom,” Of Mustapha Pasha Kamel, Mr. Blunt bears the following testimony :—

“As for Mustapha Kamel himself I kn w him personally and I have read a good deal that he has published, and I have fur Ifimja high rcspcot as an honest and consistent patriot. He is also an astonishingly able man with great political insight and power of eloquent expression. He has been reproached with changing his political connections. But all his advooacy has had thesame basis, under changing conditions, that of gaining for bis country friends ; that of trying to awake in Europe some sympathy with a liberal cause worthy of its assistance ; that of reminding Englishmen of their promises so publioly made of restoring ‘Egypt to the Egyptians.’ I am certain he is worthy of all the help English Radioal Members of Parliament can give him.”

Annexation is the logical outoome of Lord Cromer's polioy, bnt that step we cannot take. What then oan we do 1 Mr. Blunt recommends ns to restore the self.govarnment in Egypt which we destroyed in 1882.We can retrace our steps,and begin again with Lord Dufferin’s programme. Mr. Blunt says that we coold establish to-morrow a true native Government constitutionally endowed but we want a man like Sir William Wédderburn to begin-it.
Egyptian Sympathies for Turkey.
The “Tribune” devotes a leading article to to Mr. Blunt’s article, from which we extract the following :—

Mr. Blunt, who oertainly knows the Egyptians as few Europeans do, assures ns that they are not fanatioal, and indeed there has been nothing in their history to arouse fanatioism. The movements which we have usually and perhaps hastily set down to fanatioism in Turkey have really been the reply of an alarmed Turkish minority to the threats of a rebellious Christian majority. They have sprung rather from fear and indignation than from religions excitement. In Egypt there was never a rebellious Christian element, and the Moslems never dreaded it uprising, Arabjjg movement was indeed direoted partly against the rather disreputable Levantine element in the Khedive’s administration, but still more against the Turkish pashas. We do not think that the quotations from the baser sort of Arabio newspapers, foolish and violent tbongh they are, quite support tho oharge of fanaticism ; and in any event he describes these papers as venal and-ephemeral, and makes no charge against the important Nationalist organ, “El Lewa.” What these extracts do prove k however, that in the reoent Tabah dispute Egyptian sympathies were certainly with the Sultan. It is only by a series of leaps in reasoning that one oould oonolnde from this that the Egyptians - are religious fanatics so indifferent; alike to their own interests and to their prospects | of freedom as to wish to exchange an Eogli.h | occupation for direct Tarkish rule. The fact1 rather is that, finding Lord Cromer a resolute opponent of their dreams of self government, they took their revenge by sympathizing with I each of his opponents in turn. Mustapha Kamel I Pasha, for example, op to the Fashoda inoider t

and the entente tended to lean on France ; he now turns as naturally to Turkey.Jt is easy to censure ; it is harder to realise the desperation of patriots who, Je (pairing of the generosity of their conquerors, turn to any/foreign Power whioh may perohance assail us in our difficult and irregular position. The Irish have passed exactly the same phases of opinion ; they were always on the side of E igland’s enemies, not always from any natnraL. sympathy, bnt rather by way of taking revenge for our denial of their rights. But however we explain these phases of sentiment and intrigue, the moral is clear. We oannot hope to conciliate the Egyptians save by redeeming our own procurer and conceding their proper olaims. We have done little for edooa tien in Egypt, and nothirg for the development of its political capacity. To create a more domccratio school system and a modern university—these ought to be the first steps. Let ns begin to reoonoile the talent, which undoubtedly exists among the younger generation, and we shhnld probably find that Mr. Blunt’s ideal—the nationalisation of the oivil administration—is neither a remote nor a dangerous remedy.

note.p: London, Ootober 13.

Colonel G. M. Mackenzie, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, will vaoate the command of the 1st Battalion at Viotoria Barraoks, Belfast, on the 3rd November under the four years rule. Colonel Mackenzie began his military career in the 108th Madras Infantry—now the 2nd Battalion of the Inciakillings—in August, 1879, was attached to the Army Service Corps, 1888 91, w^s promoted oaptain in the former year, major in 1899, and lieutenant oolonel of the 1st Battanon, 3rd November, 1902. He served with the Istiattalion in the South African War duringijm operations in Natal, March-June, 1900, and commanded it for some time, and he oommanded the 2nd Battalion in the closing stges of the campaign in the Transvaal and Orange Colony (mentioned in despatches. Queen’s medal with four olasps). His successor has not yet been officially announced, but Major C. J. L. Davidson,

list.item: S.O., second in command of the 2nd Bat, talion at Cairo, a well-known Derry gentleman will almost to a osrtaiuty get the oommand althoogh he has oome under the age rules, and is liable to be retired before the vaoanoy ooonrs, He served with distinction in the Boer War with the 1st Battalion, and was desperately woanded at Pieter's Hill. His services earned him the D. S. 0., Queen’s medal with five olasps, King’s medal with two olasps.

note.p: Lieutenant H. C. Smith, 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers, recently c.t Cairo, has taken up the duties ot aide decamp to General Sir W.W.E.F. Forestier-Walker, Governor of Gibraltar.

Second Lieutenant W, F. Higginson, 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers’, Fermoy, has been promoted lieutenant af'er the rather long period of nearly five years. He got his commission in December, 1901.

Gentleman Cadet G. Burnham, from the Royal Military College, has been appointed a second lieutenant in the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, and will in the first instanoejoin the Reserve Squadron at Ballinoollig.
The Army Connoil has decided to abolish a number of small military stations where detachments of infantry and batteries of Royal Field Artillery are stationed. Ireland will suffer by this decision.

The War Office has established a system of interchanging officers between the British and Indian Armier and the military foroes of the British dominions beyond the seas.The Govern meut of tha Australian Commonwealth has taken full advantage of the opportunity to gain instruotidn for their officers. There is serving in Australia Brevet-Major E. C. Haag, of the 18th Hussars, a Staff College officer, in exchange tor Lieutenant-Colonel V.C.M. Sellheim C. Binow, attached to the Aldershot Army Cqrps, {or general instruo tion. Major AT.R. Lusoombo, of the Royal Australian Artillery, is serving with the Indian Army in exohange for Major C.V. Mainwaring, of the Indian Army, who is serving in Australia. The Dominion Government of Canada has Lieutenant P.B.R. Long Innés, of the Royal Australian Artillery, serving with the military foroes of Canada in exchange f or Lieutenant E Clairmonte, of the Royal Canadian Artillery, permanent foroes, who has been lent to the Australian Commonwealth military foroes by the Dominion Government of Canada. It is understood that the principle of exohanging between the home and Colonial foroes is under consideration as a farther means of forming oonneoting links between the home forces and the composite parts of our Army beyond the seas.

The Diana, Captain R. Phipps Hornby, is presently on voyage home from the Mediterranean to pay off at Dec.mber on terminating her commission on that station. This orniser will be re commissioned for further service with l ord Charles Beresford’s command by Captain H. S. Grant.
The battleship Hibernia is ^6 be ready for the pennant by the -last week of December preparatory to taking h6r place in the Atlantic Fleet as fl*g-hip of the second in command.

The armoured cruiser Eancas'er, Captain H. L. Health, serving with the Third Crniser Squadron attached to the Mediterranean F.eet, is to be sent to the China Station iu Dsoember, and her place will be taken by her sister cruiser Roxborongh, Captain Somerset A. G. Cal- thorpe, now attached to the Channel Fleet in the First Cruiser Squadron.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS. EXTRACTS FROM HOME PAPERS

p.note:
Our Obsolete Imperial Organisation.
The unworkable character cf our present Imperial organization reoeives some fresh illustration almost every day. The events oonnected with the disastrous intrusion of the party politios of this country into the delioate and difficult situation in the new South Af-i- oan oolonies- are still fresh in the pnblio reoolleotior. Hardly less unfortunate was the result of the ignorant sentimentalist agitation of a section of the House of Commons which led the Imperial Government to attempt to interfere in an unjustifiab'e manner with the ordinary powers and prerogatives of the Natal Ministry. At the present moment we have the Newfoundland controversy, which brings out the same inherent diffi inities of the present system, though in a somewhat different aspect. Here we have one of the smallest self-governing parts of the Empire passing legislation which, though in form domestio, was in substance a direct aot of retaliation upon a foreign State, and was oaloulated to give rise to international oomplioations. This legislation was passed without apparently consulting either the Imperial Government or the Government of Canada, whose interests are vitally affeoted by the relations of the United States
to the British Empire. . . The moral to be drawn from the whole inoident, in fact, as from all such incidents, is not so much that any one is to blame as that the existing system, workable enough as long as the Colonies were ontside the range of international politios, is entirely unsuited to modern conditions. Some system for effective intercommunication and continuous consultation on all questions affeoting inter-Imperial or foreign relations, and for making responsibility and power co extensive, needs to be devised and substituted for the present unworkable, regime at the earliest possible moment. (“Times.”)

div.p: Mr. Balfour’s Leadership.

' Those who are dissatisfied with the leadership of the late Prime Minister had better oross the floor of the House c f Commons, and we will wish them joy of their oompany and their oompany of them. The Conservative seotion of the party knows wall that the time is not far distant when they* may he called upon to form a new alliance, not less essentia! to the well-being ot the country than that which contributed so oonspiouously to its prosperity from 1886 till 1906. The Socialists and anti-Sooialists are makiog a sohism in the Radioal ranks, Mr. Asquith has spoken just as strongly as the Master of Elibank and Mr. J. A. Pease upon the efforts of the Socialists to capture the party. Advanced Radicals, though by no means enamoured of the doctrines of collectivism, thiuk it prudent to reprobate tin sin, but to bribe the sinner with soft words. It is not any business of ours ; but a time will come when the Liberal defenders of civilised society will have to appeal to all sympathisers for support against a common foe, and it is imperative that when that appeal is made—and it may come sooner than is expected—there should be a solid, disciplined, and loyal Unionist party to respond. (“Telegraph.”)
Efficiency must Precede Chettpness-

The fact is, that it is impossible to have a cheap Navy, We are to have economy by all means ; but the ODly method of obtaining a true economy is by the soientifio adaptation of means to ends. The object cf the British Nsvy admits of a perfectly simple statement. It is to ensnre and to maintain British supremacy upon the seas. That supremacy can only be ensured and maintained by the preservation of an absolute efficiency, and efficiency in men and ships oan only be seoured by a sea going fleet kept in oonstant praotics. We must have the best ships, the best men, the best weapons. Notone ot these things is cheap. But we must also obtain and hold a numerical superiority in sea-going ships ready for war. The new scheme directly diminishes that superiority. Nor have we only to consider the defence of these islands in this regard. The defence of the British Empire is the charge of the Navy ; and we are to provide against the possibility of attaok from more quarters than one, at places Separated from each other by thousands of miles It may be that no ex penditore which the nation could afford would adequately secure the Empire against all con- tirgenoies. But for that reason is it the more important that every ship we have should be kept efficient, and every man under training at sea. (“Standard.”)
War Stores Sentences.

xThe Army will not relii-h Mr. Haldane’s new fashioned method of virtually- substituting trial by the War Office for trial by court- martial in the oa*e of the effiters and non commissioned officers unfavourably reported on by the Stores Commission. It is not open to controversy that the official investigation brought to light wholesale corruption and stupidity, more or less permeati ng all grades except the highest, and it is quite right that those personally implicated should receive sharp punishcaeut. On that issue, the Army at large will be of one mind with Mr. Haldane and the Army Council. Bot bearing in mind bow-great was the varianoe in the evideuoe against individuals, justice required that everyone under suspicion of malpractices should be allowed a fair opportunity of proving his inno- oenoe. There is an unpleasant look of Star Chamber practioe in their being tried oolleotive- ly by an impalpable tribunal sitting in oamera. (“Globe.”)
‘‘Ungracious Acquittals."
We are glad to see that some of the officers appear to he honourably acquitted, but the

issue of a graded list of degrees of punishment and the style of an administrative paper rather than of a judicial utteranoe makes the acquittals ungraoious, while it is not easy to discriminate between the degrees of blame implied in the punishments. Important questions of prinoqle and method are involved in this form of qnasi- judioial administrative decision. (“Morning Post,”)
Mr. Haldane Defended.

The public will endorse and approve the action taken by the Army Counoil in the case of the officers who were censured by the Royal Commission on War Stores in South Africa. Among those punished there msy be oases of individual hardship. But no War Minister oould overlook the glaring faults disclosed by the Commission’s rèport, or permit suoh serious offences to pass without vigorous action. Mr. Haldane has shown no precipitation, and has fully considered the facts. The number of those acquitted-«f all blame is satisfactorily large, but eleven officers have been oeusured ; five have been oompulsorily retired ; and twelve officers and warrant officers have been discharged or retired Without pensions. It should be a useful lesson for the future.”
(“Daily Mai’.’’)
Radical Criticism.

Mr: Haldane has oertainly not erred on the side of severity in his treatment of the officers and men oeusured in various degrees by the War Stores Commission. It must be remembered that the Commission estimated the “total preventible loss to the home taxpayers” at something between three quarters of a million and one million and a qnarter. The loss was primarily due to the "smartness” and in some oases to the definitely fraudulent practices of some of the oontraotors with whom the military had to deal. But it was also due partly to oorroption and"partly to ‘irresponsibility, indifference, and want of intelligence” on the part cf the responsible officers, commissioned and non-commissioned. We must not underrate the severity of the punishment involved in retirement even under the most favourable conditions. But, allowing for this, we oannot butJeel that this million of money, more or less, changed hands, so fo say, with less friction than usually accompanies the improper transfer of a hundredth part of that som, (“Tribune.”)

note.p: NASAL CATARRH . AFFECTS HEARING.

Mr. R. J. Arlega, SOI OUy Hall Ave., Montreal, Quebec, la an old gentleman of -wide acquaintance, having served thirty-eight years in the General Post- office of Montreal, a record which speaks for itself. Concerning his use of Pernna, Mr. Arises says :
"I bave been afflicted with asset catarrh to such a degree that It affected my bearing.
“This was contracted some twenty years ago by being exposed todranghta and sudden changes ot temperature.
7 have been under the treatment of specialists and have used many drugs recommended as specifics for catarrh In the bead and throat-all to no purpose.
“About three years ago 1 was induced by a confrere in office to try Pernna.

"After some hesitation, as I had doubts as to results after so many failures, I gave Peruna a trial, and am happy to state that after using eight or ten bottles of Peruna I am much Imprdred In bearing, and In breathing through the nostrils."

For special directions everyone would read “The Dis of Life,” a copy, of whioh surrounds each bottle. Peru na is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle of six bottles for twenty-five shillings.

div.p: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.

div.head: Notice. Sudan Government. Disposal of Building Sites at Port Sudan.
div.p: The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual ' Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rent3 fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration dt the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent

Example : If a plot. is leased for a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907, then on the expiration of that term the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in' perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premiums for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particûlars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours :
Khartoum : *Office of Director of Agricul
ture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor of Khartoum Province.
Cairo : ^Office of Sudan Agent (T).
Port Sudan : Office of Inspector (Government Office) (T).
Suakin : Office of /Governor of Red Sea Province.
El Darner : Office of Governor of Berber Province.
Atbara : Office of Director cf RaUways.
Alexandria : Office of Mr. Macphérson Grant.
Port Said : Office of Dixon Bey, War Office Representative. ,
London : *Office of Col. Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster and the Sudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez : Office of Capt., Falconer, War Office Representative.

For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Further information will lie obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documents on applieation in writing to The Diree t jr of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.
* Copies of the Documents will be obtainable after 1st Octobor 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. or 1 Shilling per copy at the Offices marked with an asterisk.

div.head: Government du Soudan. Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Sudan
div.p: Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochainement disposer, par voie d’adjudication d’environ 400 parcelles de terrains à bâtir à Port- Soudan.

Les dites parcelltes seront données à bail emphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années à partir du 1er Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, à Charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le, lojær ne sera payable qu’à partir de la date de l’apeptation de l’offre.
Les baux "seront renouvelables à perpétuité moyennant un loyer variable fiié à la fin de chaque terme, soit d’accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant* le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d’àugmenta ion de loyer.

EXEMPLE : ‘ Si une parcelle <le terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à partir *du 1er Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, à l’expiration de ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (à condition d’observer les conditions Æu bail) d’obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi à perpétuité. *
• La loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s’il était libre de construction.

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotiques dont s’agit ; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que le soumissionaire est disposé à payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun dçs lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement à la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offre» doivent être faites par soumission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivent être reçues à Khartoum avant le 1er Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l’adjudication et de la concession, la fprmule de soumission, spécification du bail, seront à la disposition du Public* à partir du 1er Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-après indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum*—Bureau du Directeur de l’Agriculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le' Caire* Bureau de l’agent du Gouvernement du Soudan (T).
Port-Soudan*:—Bureau de l’Inspecteur (Bureau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakim—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province et de la Mer Rouge.
Wadi-Halfa—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de B[alfa.
El-Damer—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Berber. *
Atbara—Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Alexandrie—Bureau de Mr. Macphérson Grant.
Port-Saïd—Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.
Londres—Bureau du Colonel Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez—pureau du Capitaine Falconer,- Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.

Pour la commodité des acheteurs éventuels les conditions d’adjudication et fie concession ont été traduites en arabe et en français et des copiés de ces traductions, dans les/deux langues, peuvent être obtenues à partir du 1er Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 par copie, aux bureaux mentionnés d ins la liste ci-dessus, qui sont suivis d’une lettre majuscule T.

Des informations supplémentaires peuvent être obtenues après publications des documents ci-dessus mentionnés, moyennant dehiande écrite adressée au Directeur dé l’Agriculture et des Terrains, à Khartoum.
* Aux bureaux marqués d’une astérisque, copies des documents pourront être obtenues àpartir du 12 Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 ou un Bhelling par oopio.28497-2M
